title: Do corporate governance mechanisms influence CEO compensation? An empirical investigation of UK companies
abstractText:
CEO compensation packages have been a focus of much academic and media interest.    One important question is whether corporate governance mechanisms can play a significant role in determining the level and structure of executive compensation. The literature suggests that corporate governance mechanisms may help to reduce the agency conflicts between executives and shareholders, and hence have an impact on compensation policy. Those mechanisms include ownership and board structure of companies. In this paper the aim is to investigate whether corporate governance mechanisms have an impact on the level of CEO compensation for a sample of quoted UK companies from 1997 to 2004.  In particular, the study will examine whether institutional shareholders influence the level of executive compensation and pay-performance sensitivity. Additionally, the role of managerial shareholdings, and the board structure of companies are also examined. 

This study will contribute to the literature by examining the role of a comprehensive set of corporate governance variables in determining the structure of CEO compensation. It will be also the first study that explores the impact of corporate governance mechanisms on the level of CEO compensation and the pay for performance sensitivity for the UK companies.  In the empirical analysis, I this study will employ panel data estimation technique.
